X.T: Do we have evidence for new physics?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The mass of the Higgs boson, the dark energy, and the matter/antimatter asymetry do not require new physics. But it is true that we need a quantum gravity theory, an explanation for neutrino mass, and understanding if dark matter is real. No of these requires a new particle accelerator.

X.T: What Could Explain the Gallium Anomaly?
X.ST: Physicists have ruled out a mundane explanation for the strange findings of an old Soviet experiment, leaving open the possibility that the results point to a new fundamental particle.

X.T: What Is Entropy? A Measure of Just How Little We Really Know.
X.ST: Exactly 200 years ago, a French engineer introduced an idea that would quantify the universe’s inexorable slide into decay. But entropy, as it’s currently understood, is less a fact about the world than a reflection of our growing ignorance. Embracing that truth is leading to a rethink of everything from rational decision-making to the limits of machines.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: From SadiCarno to the subjectivity of entropy and observational entropy, SusanneStill‘s study of Szilard engineSzilard’s engine, JohnBechhoefer and NataliaAres’ experiments…

X.T: ‘Last Hope’ Experiment Finds Evidence for Unknown Particles

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Fermilab Muon g-2 experiment confirms the discrepancy between the measurement and the Standard Model computation. Meanwhile, some searchers claim to have computed a better value for the Standard Model and this one matches the experimental measurement.

X.T: A Deepening Crisis Forces Physicists to Rethink Structure of Nature’s Laws
X.ST: For three decades, researchers hunted in vain for new elementary particles that would have explained why nature looks the way it does. As physicists confront that failure, they’re reexamining a longstanding assumption: that big stuff consists of smaller stuff.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some physicists start to question the IR/UV decoupling, the fact that phenomena at a given level can be analysed by ignoring the details of the physics laws at a smaller scale.

X.T: What Is the Nature of Time?
X.ST: Time is all around us: in the language we use, in the memories we revisit and in our predictions of the future. But what exactly is it? The physicist and Nobel laureate Frank Wilczek joins Steve Strogatz to discuss the fundamental hallmarks of time.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some miscellanous subjects: time, relativity, axions…

X.T: Nathan Seiberg on How Math Might Complete the Ultimate Physics Theory
X.ST: Even in an incomplete state, quantum field theory is the most successful physical theory ever discovered. Nathan Seiberg, one of its leading architects, talks about the gaps in QFT and how mathematicians could fill them.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The mathematics of QFT.
